message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with nipple discharge, an inverted nipple, and dilated subareolar ducts on the right, which are all consistent with duct ectasia. The firm, stable mass under the inverted nipple in the left breast and the tubular calcifications on the mammogram suggest the presence of an intraductal papilloma. Periareolar fistula and periductal mastitis are less likely based on the presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The discharge from the left nipple, dilated subareolar ducts on the right breast, and the mammogram that reveals tubular calcifications suggest duct ectasia. Periareolar fistula and periductal mastitis usually present with purulent discharge and are associated with inflammation and pain. Intraductal papilloma may cause nipple discharge, but is more commonly associated with a palpable mass and is not usually bilateral.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has discharge from the left nipple and dilated subareolar ducts on the right breast, suggesting duct ectasia. The firm, stable mass under the inverted nipple in her left breast and the mammogram showing tubular calcifications suggest a possible intraductal papilloma, but it is not the most likely diagnosis based on the given information. Periareolar fistula and periductal mastitis both usually present with pain or tenderness, which is absent in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The gray-green nipple discharge and increasing amount of discharge in combination with a firm mass under an inverted nipple suggest duct ectasia. The dilated subareolar ducts seen on the right breast also support this diagnosis. Periareolar fistula would have a visible opening on the skin surface. Periductal mastitis would typically be associated with pain and inflammation. Intraductal papilloma would have a bloody nipple discharge. The presence of tubular calcifications on mammogram is also consistent with duct ectasia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest that she has a discharge from the nipple, and physical examination reveals dilated subareolar ducts. This is consistent with the diagnosis of duct ectasia, which can also produce a firm mass under the inverted nipple. Tubular calcifications are seen in duct ectasia. Periareolar fistula is not consistent with physical examination findings. Periductal mastitis is a rare inflammatory condition, and intraductal papilloma usually produces bloody discharge.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of a gray greenish discharge and progressively increasing amount suggest duct ectasia. The presence of dilated subareolar ducts and tubular calcifications on mammogram support this diagnosis. Periareolar fistula is characterized by a single orifice on the nipple, periductal mastitis can cause nipple discharge but is often accompanied by breast pain, and intraductal papilloma usually causes a single-duct discharge and is characterized by a small, soft mass that can often be felt.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of discharge from the nipple and dilated subareolar ducts on one breast suggests duct ectasia. The mammogram findings of tubular calcifications are also consistent with duct ectasia. Periareolar fistula typically presents with recurrent infection and discharge from a single duct. Periductal mastitis typically presents with breast pain and swelling. Intraductal papilloma typically presents with a single bloody nipple discharge.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, such as the gray-green discharge and inverted nipple, suggest ductal involvement. The dilated subareolar ducts on the right and the calcifications on mammogram suggest duct ectasia. Options A and C are less likely and option D usually presents with a palpable mass.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of nipple discharge, an inverted nipple with a mass, and dilated subareolar ducts suggest duct ectasia. The mammogram confirmed the presence of calcifications, which is a common finding in duct ectasia. Periareolar fistula usually presents with discharge from an opening on the skin, not the nipple itself. Periductal mastitis typically presents with painful breast lump, while intraductal papilloma usually presents with bloody discharge.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of nipple discharge and dilated subareolar ducts suggest duct ectasia. The mammogram showing tubular calcifications is also consistent with duct ectasia. Periareolar fistula is another possibility but it usually presents with a unilateral nipple discharge associated with inflammation or infection. Periductal mastitis presents with swelling and erythema around the nipple and is associated with smoking. Intraductal papilloma presents with unilateral bloody discharge and a mass that can be felt on physical examination.
